704997f-a.title: Brooklyn: Hoyt Street - Fulton Street
704997f-a.text:
Hoyt Street, at the S. W. corner of Fulton Street,
viewing north toward the latter. Note the I. R. T.
subway entrance and a W. P. A. shack (right), where the
federal agency is conducting a wewer project.
November 27, 1936
Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIUE

704996f-a.title: Brooklyn: Hoyt Street - Fulton Street
704996f-a.text:
Hoyt Street, at the S. E. corner of Fulton Street,
looking north toward the latter and showing Namm's Depart-
ment Store. The W. P. A. is cknducting a sewer project
here.
November 27, 1936
Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project
CREDIT LINE IMTERATIVE

704505f-a.title: Brooklyn: Fulton Street - Bridge Street
704505f-a.text:
Fastened to the wall of a buildinglocatea on Fulton St. near
Bridge St., Brooklyn, is this plache tella,a story that had
its beginning more than three centurie ago.1
a, Dwo.ktgw. tWW2r2
In those early colonial times.were open spaces,dotted with
scattered structures. .unong these stood an ocatgon Reformed
Church in which, about July 4th., 1661, Carel DeBevoise, who
had arrived a scant two years before as an emigrant from
Eolland, conducted the first school in Brooklyn.
From the record we find ''Carel Dehevoise, a highly educated
French Protestant, with his wife - nee Sophia Van Lodensteyn-
and three children had sailed from Amsterdam, Netherlands, on
the ship Otter, in February, 1659 and arrived on these shores
shobtly thereafter.
Carel DeBevoise was more than schoolmaster:
NEe was required
as the rescript testifies, to act as court messenger, to serve
somcions, conduct the services of the church, to lead the cdoir
on Sundays, ring the bell for public worship, take charge of
the school, and perform other occasional services. Re can
appreciate his embarrassment, and sympathize with his appre-
hensions in the performance of so many and such conflicting
duties as are specially named; b t when the monstrous addition
is affixed 'and such other occasional services as the very
w0NINREE09fN9 and ponderous schout and the dignified and exaoting
schepens should enact for his worriment,' human emotion is
too feeble to be commensurate with the demmand.''
Yet insignificant ss was the beginning the light has never
heen cuenched. The tablet stresses this thought in the words:
The Spark Rere kindled Has Become a Great Flaie
Tllumining the Path of Youth Unto Tisdom and Iorth.
